glaciers=solid mass of water, conveys forces through to it's base creating 'circumstances'.  Carbon rich masses=solid mass of geology, (either seized in the crust or ebbing around in magma) conveys forces through to its sides; un-meltable carbon rich masses can be many factors more dense than the straight they're seized in: high carbon masses won't shear away during subduction, therefor are left above (behind). Here earthquakes share matter dividing it between the unbreakable mass and the inevitable subduction.

Welcome to the Pacific Northwest (PNW).  We live in Portland, a bit further south of where you are visiting and we have our own big mountain - Mt Hood.  In any case it is very similar, a lot of light rain and moderately cold temperatures in Oct-May that help grow the beautiful forests.  The real payback for that is the gorgeous months of July and August.  Now, don't get me wrong, we don't suffer inside through 10 months to get two awesome ones, most of us are outside 12 months a year.  The rain is not really that big of a deal, it is pretty light, and there are usually sun breaks - some times a for just an hour or so, and some times for a few days.  Not only that, there is WAY to much to see for only 2 months a year.  Have fun, enjoy the outside, pay no mind to the rain, and shhh don't tell too many people how pretty it is.

Wonderful video. Suggestion for your next road trip... A little further south, in a single day drive you can go from the shores of the pacific ocean, through 5 climate zones, and end up at stonehenge in the western high desert. Passing through rainforest, and spactular waterfalls, as you drive eastward along the columbia river. Starting at Astoria Oregon, drive east, and set your destination to "Sam Hill" in washington, just across the bridge from Biggs Junction Oregon. Biggs Junction has its own type of jasper, and "Sam Hill" has a full size replica of stonehenge. as you make your way between the two points you can stop at vistas like crown point, and visit waterfalls like the spectacular Multnomah Falls.

Aside from the advertisement for Subaru I enjoyed the content. Having hiked and camped around the peninsula for over forty years, several years ago I became interested in the geological history watching a presentation about exotic terranes by Nick Zentner at Central Washington University. The peninsula was not originally part of the continent. It was rafted in from the south and west along with most of the land west of Spokane. Mr Zentner is entertaining and his presentations are captivating. For anyone interested in rather detailed discussion of the subject I highly recommend watching the presentation on Exotic Terranes of the Pacific Northwest at https://youtu.be/fibDx4CDNRc. The presentations are an hour but for those who are interested it is worth it. His other presentations are all excellent and there is no advertisement.
